title: Your first Quarto project
text:
Goal: Create the first project and give some light detail to the user.
Create the project.
Walk through what files it creates.
Explain the files (own section for each).
Spend a lot of time with _quarto.yml.
quarto render the project.

title: Quarto Projects Overview
text: We’ve seen how Quarto can render the same document containing different programming languages to several different formats using quarto render. In this next section, we’ll move from rendering a single document to rendering a project. Here, a project means a collection of documents, such as a website or a book.

title: Your First Quarto Document
text:
Create a simple Quarto document in R/Python.
End with rendering it to different document formats (Word, pdf, latex)

title: Example R
text:
This is a Quarto document containing R code.

plot(1:10)

title: Different Output Formats
text: Take the document we had above and render it to some slide formats.

title: Example Python Document
text:
This is a Quarto document containing Python code.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

t = [x for x in range(1, 11)]

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(t, t);

plt.show()

title: Example R + Python
text:
This is a Quarto document containing both R and Python code.
Here is some R code:

plot(1:10)




And here is some Python code:

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

t = [x for x in range(1, 11)]

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(t, t);

plt.show()

title: Hello Quarto
text:
Quarto is an open-source scientific and technical publishing system built on Pandoc. Quarto documents are authored using markdown, an easy to write plain text format.
In addition to the core capabilities of Pandoc, Quarto includes:

Support for embedding output from Python, R, and Julia via integration with Jupyter and Knitr .
A variety of extensions to Pandoc markdown useful for technical writing including callouts (admonitions), cross-references, sub-figures, layout panels, hover-able citations and footnotes, and more.
A project system for rendering groups of documents at once, sharing options across documents, and producing aggregate output like books and websites.
HTML output based on Bootstrap (including support for Bootswatch themes).
Automatic installation of required LaTeX packages when rendering PDF output.

The overall design of Quarto is influenced heavily by R Markdown, however unlike R Markdown the architecture is language agnostic. In its current iteration, Quarto can render plain markdown, Jupyter Notebooks, and Knitr (Rmd) documents.

text: Up next is Installation - we’ll install Quarto and additional computational dependencies to get you up and running with Quarto.
